Groups

Sep 7, 2019

References


  • Abstract Algebra: An Introduction, 3rd Edition by Thomas W. Hungerford.


Definition


A group is a nonempty set of elements with a binary operation that satisfies four properties

  1. Closure: For all , we have .
  2. Associativity: For all , we have .
  3. Identity: There exists an identity element such that for any , we have .
  4. Inverse: For all , there exists an inverse element such that .

Moreover, if the group satisfies commutativity so that for all , we have , then is an abelian group.

Order of an Element


Given a group and an element , the order of the element , , is the smallest positive integer such that . If there is no such element then has an infinite order.

Theorem: A nonempty subset of a group is a subgroup if
(i) for all , we have .
(ii) for all , we have .

Proof:
The closure property is satisfied by (i). Since is a group then we know associativity holds for all elements including elements in . The inverse exists by (ii). For the identity element, since is not empty then we must have some element . We also must have by the inverse property. Therefore, we must have by the closure property.
